awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Hybrid Quadrupole Mass Spectrometer with an Ultra-High Pressure Chromatograph
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemical Instrumentation Programs. Professor Elizabeth Stone from the University of Iowa and colleagues James Gloer, Keri Hornbuckle and David Cwiertny are acquiring a hybrid quadrupole-Orbitrap mass spectrometer with electrospray ionization (ESI) capabilities and equipped with an ultra high pressure chromatograph (UPLC).  In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized and the ions' masses are measured.  An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. Some of the programs using the instrument are the Iowa Sloan Center for Exemplary Mentoring, Summer Research Opportunities Program, the Iowa Biosciences Academy, and an NSF-supported Sustainable Water Development Program.  Advancement of scientific knowledge in the areas of environmental chemistry, water treatment, bioremediation, natural products, medicinal chemistry, and food safety contribute to the achievement of societally-relevant outcomes.

The acquisition award enhances research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the characterization of molecular atmospheric aerosols and improves drinking water quality. The mass spectrometer is also used to identify the outcomes of steroids and other pharmaceuticals in the environment and bioactive products from fungi. The instrument also serves researchers evaluating toxicity and remediation of polychlorinated biphenyls as well as those characterizing environmental contaminants. In addition, the mass spectrometer aids in the discovery of transformation products and pathways of emerging water contaminants, and investigations of surface films at active environmental interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this major research instrumentation grant, an ultra-high resolution mass spectrometer and ultra-high pressure liquid chromatograph were acquired to enable scientific research advances in fundamental science and engineering research at the University of Iowa. This instrument operates in the University of Iowa’s High Resolution Mass Spectrometry Facility (HRMSF) that provides an established platform for instrument management, research training, and accessibility for the university campus and surrounding community.

With capabilities of high-resolution accurate mass and tandem mass spectrometry, this instrument is widely utilized by researchers for qualitative and quantitative analysis of small molecules.  At the University of Iowa, more than 57 researchers across 27 individual research groups have utilized this instrument. This instrument has fostered new discoveries and methodologies across many areas of research, including chemistry, environmental engineering, chemical engineering, toxicology, medicine, and pharmacy. As examples of its use, this instrument is used by synthetic chemists to characterize new materials and by engineers to study the chemical composition of surface waters. This instrument also provides a valuable service to the surrounding communities, including nine primarily undergraduate institutions and two local companies that utilize it for compound identification and confirmation. Compared to previous instrumentation, the newly acquired instrument provides much needed improvements to resolution, accuracy, data acquisition and mining techniques, and signal-to-noise. Consequently, its qualitative and quantitative capabilities have enabled new research avenues and research awards to University of Iowa researchers.

Each research application provides an opportunity to integrate state-of-the-art mass spectrometry technology into the training of researchers in their respective fields. Eight University of Iowa researchers have been trained as hands-on users of this instrument, which includes safe operating procedures for the instrument, familiarization with data acquisition software, operation and performance assessment, tandem mass spectrometry optimization, and data analysis. After completion of training, instrument users schedule instrument time using the HRMSF on-line scheduling system. HRMSF staff continue to assist users in running specialized experiments. Many more researchers have gained data from this instrument, by submitting samples and analyzing the resulting data.

Educational initiatives have integrated the new instrument technology into an increasing number of undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Iowa. These courses span introductory chemistry, advanced chemistry laboratories, and graduate courses in Mass Spectrometry, Spectroscopic Methods in Organic Chemistry, and Foundations of Environmental Chemistry and Microbiology. Through these courses, students are gaining insight to the theory and operation of this new instrument and its capabilities for chemical measurements and research.  Overall, this new instrument has advanced ongoing research and training at the University of Iowa and has built capacity for our community to advance the frontiers in science and engineering research.
